doc.title: MeiDong Auto
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/1H25 miss updates on ultra-luxury car tax stop of high rebate on auto finance1H25 miss updates on ultra-luxury car tax s_2025-08-29

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: NEUTRAL | PO: 2.20 HKD | Price: 2.10 HKD

Meidong (MD)'s 1H25 revenue was RMB10.1bn, down \(5\%\) YoY. New- car revenue fell \(8\%\) YoY to RMB7.9bn. New- car sales volume up \(8\%\) YoY, while blended ASP was down \(14\%\) YoY. New- car sales GPM dropped by 5.7ppt YoY/3.5ppt HoH to \(- 10.8\%\) , with Porsche /Lexus/BMW/Toyota at similar level. If we include auto finance commission, adjusted new car GPM would be around \(- 2\%\) . Porsche provided RMB25k/car additional subsidy for 5M25 with conditions on 3Q25 volume sales. BMW announced in August RMB6k/car subsidy for 2Q25 and RMB17k/car subsidy for 3Q25. These rebates are not fully recognized in MD's 1H25 results. AM revenue rose \(6\%\) YoY to RMB2.2bn, driven by serviced units up \(6\%\) YoY. AM GPM was \(60.4\%\) , 0.6ppt YoY/flat HoH. 1H25 recorded net loss of RMB815mn, in line with preliminary earnings. If we exclude non- operating items (RMB868bn impairment, RMB92mn loss on convertible bond, offset by RMB218mn one- off tax impacts), 1H25 net loss would be RMB48mn, vs. RMB218mn in 1H24.

After China lowered threshold for ultra- luxury car consumption tax to RMB900k models in July, MD saw sales volume of its above- threshold cars dropped notably in Aug. vs. 1H25. Currently Auto OEMs provide subsidy to cover the tax difference but it remains uncertain when OEM subsidy will fade out. After suspension of high- rebate for auto finance in July, MD saw its auto finance commission rate dropped by 5ppt to \(5\%\) , while its price discount only narrowed by 1- 2ppt - so MD's adjusted new car GPM worsened by 3- 4ppt. Meanwhile, customers pay \(3\%\) higher prices than before so volume sales dropped. MD believes it takes time for consumers to adapt to the new car price levels.

Factoring in 1H25 results, we expect 2025E to be loss- making and lower 2026E EPS by \(62\%\) . We apply 15x target PER to 2026E EPS (rolled over from 2025) and derive PO at HKD2.2. 15x is MD's 5- year historical average P/E, reflecting likely stabilizing traditional luxury brand business. We used 9x previously (1SD below historical average). We reiterate Neutral on MD for its strong management abilities to navigate amid industry downcycle.

Autos/Car Manufacturers

China MeiDong (MeiDong) is one of the fastest- growing premium car dealerships in China, with a strong focus on luxury brands in lower tier cities. Its brand portfolio includes BMW, Porsche, Lexus, Audi, Toyota and Hyundai. In addition to new car sales, it also offers after- sales services including maintenance and repairs.

We have a Neutral on Meidong. On the negative side, (1) sales of BMW models put Meidong's new- car margin under pressure, (2) sales of Porsche brand faces weakening demand in China due to the intensified competition from Chinese high- end EV brands and weak macro. On the positive side, we like it for (1) earnings recovery outlook aided by operating expenses control, (2) prudent and stable strategy well protecting Meidong from industry downturn.
Price to Book Value 1.3x
1H25 recorded net loss of RMB815mn, in line with preliminary earnings

We derive our PO of HKD2.2, using our target P/E multiple of 15x (five- year historical average one- year forward estimated P/E) over its 2026E EPS. We use five- year historical average as it captures a full automobile cycle in China. We believe its five- year historical average is appropriate, reflecting likely stabilizing traditional luxury brand business, despite China auto dealer industry is going through challenges, where new car sales margin is under pressure amid weak consumer spending sentiment and competition from electric vehicle brands.

Upside risk: (1) faster- than- expected recovery of luxury brand new car sales demand, (2) faster- than- expected growth in the number of stores or average sales per store, (3) higher- than- expected growth in after- sales services revenue, (4) more successful than expected profit improvement of acquisitions.

Downside risks: (1) slowdown in luxury car sales, (2) inability to ramp up the store count, (3) increased competition around its existing stores, (3) threat from increasing penetration of electric vehicles to Meidong's brands, (4) failure of pending store acquisitions to close, (5) execution risk of integrating acquired stores.
